metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Factors are used to categorize data. Examples of factors are:
content.html: Factors are used to categorize data. Examples of factors are:

content.text: To create a factor, use the factor() function and add a vector as argument:
content.html: To create a factor, use the factor() function and add a vector as argument:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
# Create a factormusic_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", 
  "Rock", "Jazz"))# Print the factormusic_genre

content.code:
# Create a factormusic_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz",
"Rock", "Jazz"))# Print the factormusic_genre

syntax_highlighting.text:
# Create a factormusic_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", 
 "Rock", "Jazz"))# Print the factormusic_genre

content.code_html:
# Create a factor
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"))

# Print the factor
music_genre

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
# Create a factormusic_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", 
  "Rock", "Jazz"))# Print the factormusic_genre

content.text: You can see from the example above that that the factor has four levels (categories): Classic, Jazz, Pop and Rock.
content.html: You can see from the example above that that the factor has four levels (categories): Classic, Jazz, Pop and Rock.

content.text: To only print the levels, use the levels() function:
content.html: To only print the levels, use the levels() function:

content.code_html:
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"))

levels(music_genre)

content.text: You can also set the levels, by adding the levels argument inside the factor() function:
content.html: You can also set the levels, by adding the levels argument inside the factor() function:

content.code_html:
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"), levels = c("Classic", "Jazz", "Pop", "Rock", "Other"))

levels(music_genre)

content.text: Use the length() function to find out how many items there are in the factor:
content.html: Use the length() function to find out how many items there are in the factor:

content.code_html:
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"))

length(music_genre)

content.text: To access the items in a factor, refer to the index number, using [] brackets:
content.html: To access the items in a factor, refer to the index number, using [] brackets:

content.code_html:
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"))

music_genre[3]

content.text: To change the value of a specific item, refer to the index number:
content.html: To change the value of a specific item, refer to the index number:

content.code_html:
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"))

music_genre[3] <- "Pop"

music_genre[3]

content.text: Note that you cannot change the value of a specific item if it is not already specified in the factor. The following example will produce an error:
content.html: Note that you cannot change the value of a specific item if it is not already specified in the factor. The following example will produce an error:

content.code_html:
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"))

music_genre[3] <- "Opera"

music_genre[3]

content.text: However, if you have already specified it inside the levels argument, it will work:
content.html: However, if you have already specified it inside the levels argument, it will work:

content.code_html:
music_genre <- factor(c("Jazz", "Rock", "Classic", "Classic", "Pop", "Jazz", "Rock", "Jazz"), levels = c("Classic", "Jazz", "Pop", "Rock", "Opera"))

music_genre[3] <- "Opera"

music_genre[3]
